In one generation, many games with several rounds r = 1,2,...,Ω are played between groups of individuals chosen at random (herein we typically concentrate on the two-player game, but in methods we show that this is not a fundamental restriction of our model; see Methods section: Group Size). Each individual’s final payoff, π
i , is then calculated as the average payoff of all games played by the individual in that generation. This payoff π
i is translated into a fitness value f
i = exp[ π
i ]
45 . Since payoff determines fitness, this means that the strategy that incurs the highest payoffs also has the highest probability of being transferred into the next generation.
